projects.name: FPGA Reflex Game
projects.description: A reflex-testing game built entirely in hardware on an FPGA using Verilog. Features a six-digit text display and keypad for user input, challenging players to hit correct targets in time.
projects.inspiration: I wanted to move beyond software and explore hardware-level programming — understanding how games can exist as circuits instead of code.
projects.workflow: I implemented the game logic, timing, and input systems in Verilog on a custom MU0 processor. This required designing modules, state machines, and precise timing signals.
projects.takeaways: The project gave me a solid grasp of digital design, hardware debugging, and the fundamentals of low-level computation.

projects.name: FPGA Crossy Road
projects.description: A hardware recreation of the classic Crossy Road game built on an FPGA. Includes VGA output, logic handling, and interactive gameplay implemented directly in hardware.
projects.inspiration: After building my reflex game, I wanted to push my FPGA skills further by creating a recognizable, interactive experience with graphics and animation.
projects.workflow: I developed VGA modules, sprite renderers, and input handling logic entirely in Verilog. The game runs in real time, demonstrating how digital logic can create dynamic visuals.
projects.takeaways: This taught me to think in hardware pipelines — how timing, memory, and pixel rendering all combine to form an interactive game.

projects.name: Genetic Algorithms
projects.description: An exploration of evolutionary computing — using genetic algorithms to train AI agents to play games like Snake and Flappy Bird.
projects.inspiration: I’ve always been fascinated by how simple principles of evolution can lead to intelligent behavior. This project was my way of bringing that to life in code.
projects.workflow: I simulated populations of neural networks that evolved over generations using selection, crossover, and mutation to improve performance. Pygame was used for visualizing each generation’s progress.
projects.takeaways: I learned about reinforcement learning concepts, optimization, and how emergent behavior can arise from simple rules.

projects.name: Battleship Solitaire Generator
projects.description: An automated puzzle generator that creates and validates Battleship Solitaire puzzles with unique solutions and difficulty ratings.
projects.inspiration: I’ve always loved logic puzzles and wanted to see if I could teach a program to design them intelligently, just as humans do.
projects.workflow: I implemented a constraint satisfaction solver to validate puzzles and a generator that tweaks difficulty based on board size and rule density.
projects.takeaways: I gained experience with backtracking algorithms, search optimization, and procedural content generation.

projects.name: Nuclear Whiskers
projects.description: A physics-based 2D bunker fighting game built in Python’s Tkinter. Includes projectile physics, gameloop systems, and a custom GUI.
projects.inspiration: I wanted to learn how to create games without relying on a dedicated game engine — focusing instead on the math, physics, and raw logic behind it.
projects.workflow: Using Tkinter, I built a canvas-based game engine from scratch with custom rendering loops, collision detection, and input handling.
projects.takeaways: This project strengthened my understanding of GUI frameworks and game physics fundamentals.

projects.name: PyPSA-Eur Research
projects.description: A research project using PyPSA-Eur to model European power system scenarios, analyzing renewable integration, grid optimization, and energy transition pathways.
projects.inspiration: Energy systems are a key challenge for our generation. I wanted to understand how modeling frameworks can influence real sustainability decisions.
projects.workflow: I worked with PyPSA-Eur datasets to run simulations on renewable integration and visualized the outcomes using Geopandas and Matplotlib.
projects.takeaways: I learned how large-scale energy models operate and how data visualization plays a critical role in energy policy analysis.

projects.name: Battery Dispatch Model
projects.description: An economic modeling tool that optimizes solar battery dispatch strategies by analyzing cost, peak shaving, and arbitrage opportunities.
projects.inspiration: I was fascinated by how data and modeling can drive renewable energy adoption. This project let me explore the economics behind it.
projects.workflow: I built optimization routines in Python using Pandas for data handling and Matplotlib for performance visualization, running simulations on varying usage profiles.
projects.takeaways: I gained insights into modeling, optimization, and the intersection between economics and renewable energy systems.

projects.name: Hyperloop Manchester Website
projects.description: The official website for the University of Manchester’s Hyperloop Society. Showcases events, projects, and recruitment using a clean, responsive layout.
projects.inspiration: As part of the society, I wanted to create a professional online presence that reflected the innovation of our projects.
projects.workflow: I designed and built the website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, focusing on accessibility, performance, and design consistency.
projects.takeaways: I learned to balance technical execution with design thinking, producing a polished public-facing product.

projects.name: LinguaVault
projects.description: A mobile app for learning Chinese using interactive flashcards, spaced repetition, and stroke-order animations to aid memorization.
projects.inspiration: I wanted to make learning Chinese more engaging and data-driven, combining my interest in linguistics and app development.
projects.workflow: Built in Android Studio using Java, I implemented SRS algorithms, user progress tracking, and custom animation logic for character strokes.
projects.takeaways: I explored mobile UX design and algorithmic scheduling — key aspects of effective educational app development.

projects.name: Maze Generator
projects.description: A visual tool that generates mazes in real time using algorithms like breadth-first search and depth-first search, with pathfinding demonstrations.
projects.inspiration: I love visual algorithms — this project was born from wanting to ‘see’ how BFS and DFS explore space differently.
projects.workflow: I implemented the algorithms in Python with Pygame visualizations and configurable parameters for maze size and complexity.
projects.takeaways: This reinforced my understanding of search algorithms and how to visualize computational processes clearly.
